ratings.comment: Dr. Olson is a fantastic professor! She is passionate about the subject and she conveys her passion really well. She also loves to read interesting papers and is very helpful. She has participation activities almost every lecture, so don't skip. Her lectures are fun anyway. All the tangents that she goes on are usually relevant or informative.

She was an interesting lecturer. Prepare to write papers on unique subjects. There is only a midterm and a few pop quizzes. All the other grades are from discussion participation, papers and the BIG final project. Hope that you get a good group, it could make or break your grade.

Dr. Olson is funny and goofy, and knows the material really well, but she tends to go off on tangents in lecture. Additionally, this class has a huge amount of essays and projects for a 3-credit class, and the parameters aren't always very clear. If you're prepared to work your butt off, it's still a fun time though.

The lectures seemed pointless, it seemed like we really didn't actually learn anything. Most of the grading is based off of 3 papers, an online midterm, and a huge group project which takes a lot of effort. There is a ton of reading every week. The grading of assignments seemed random. You also need a 95% to get an A which is ridiculous.

She gets off track easily, assigns roughly 70 pages of reading each week, and the lectures are basically pointless. The guidelines are not very clear. The expectations are higher than what the paperproject guidelines suggest, and you need a 95% to get an A in the class (Which is completely crazy). Would not take again.

She's a sweet person, and she likes to have a laugh. She'll throw pop quizzes at you to make sure you did the readings (super long). Approachable. She genuinely wants to see her students take an interest in the subject, and do well. There is a big group project instead of a final. Lectures seem random, but if you pay attention, they come together.

Lectures are pretty boring. Sometimes they'll be interesting or when there's a guest speaker. She expects you to act like this class is your #1 priority. Class is mandatory cause of one question quizzes on readings, but you can get by with skimming and getting lucky. Heads up: folklore isnt about reading stories. Yea...i was disappointed too.

Extremely boring class with mandatory attendance (drop an entire letter grade if you miss 3 classes). Terrible lectures; rarely stays on topic. Lots of useless busywork and severe procrastination on getting out the guidelines for work (3 days before a major assignment was due we finally received guidelines on how to do it).

Oh, where to start.  No textbook, but online readings are torture. Often 2 readings per lecture, 20ish pages each, on topics such as barns, yard work, or cooking. Lecture isn't interesting, but it's not awful at the same time. For the final project, she gives you a paper about it in November and then doesn't say another word about it.  Bad class.

I'm not a huge fan of this class. It's not terribly hard but at the end of the semester the workload increases dramatically. The semester project is very vague and she didn't really talk about it at all and neither did the TAs. the readings are so long and boring but you have to read them because they are the basis of the final.

Interesting lecturer, boring readings. The class isn't difficult, but instructions for things like the semester project are really vague, so get clarity often from your TA. Overall, a good ethnic studies class with dry, but easy material.

Hilarious lecturer!  The readings she gives are long and boring, but her lectures definitely make up for that.  The tests are very fair and cover only what you've gone over in class.  She made this class bordering on fun.

This on-line class is surprisingly a lot of work but it's definitely not impossible.  It's also a refreshing change for an ethnic studies class - you learn a lot about Norwegians, Finnish, Polish cultures, etc.  Make sure you do the readings, they help boost your discussion grade.
Is completely enthusiastic and knowledgeable about Hmong studies.  A really enlivening and interesting lecturer!
